keyTakeAways: Mahmoud Khalil, a legal permanent resident and Palestinian rights activist, was detained by immigration authorities in March 2025 over his campus activism at Columbia University and is currently appealing a lower court’s release order.
The government argues that Khalil’s presence has adverse foreign policy consequences due to his advocacy for Palestinian rights, invoking a provision allowing deportation for such reasons.
Khalil was the first prominent Palestinian rights advocate to be detained over activism, signaling a broader pattern of targeting student activists for supporting Palestinian causes.
The ACLU’s Bobby Hodgson asserts that the government’s use of broad foreign policy deportation powers is unconstitutional and violates the First Amendment's protection of free speech.
A prior immigration judge ruled in favor of the government, ordering Khalil’s removal, but the decision is being appealed to the Board of Immigration Appeals and possibly to a circuit court.
A separate federal judge ruled that the Trump administration’s crackdown on Palestine solidarity activists was unlawful, as it violated free speech protections.
Khalil’s case is not resolved; both the habeas corpus petition and the deportation process are under appeal, leaving him and others in similar situations free at this time.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mahmoud Khalil, a legal permanent resident and Palestinian solidarity activist, was detained in March 2025 after his activism at Columbia University drew government attention. The U.S. government seeks to deport him, claiming his presence has adverse foreign policy consequences, while his lawyers argue that such deportation powers are unconstitutional and violate free speech protections. Khalil was released in June by a lower court through a habeas corpus petition, but the deportation case continues, with the immigration judge’s decision being appealed to the Board of Immigration Appeals and potentially to a circuit court. The ACLU, led by Bobby Hodgson, asserts that ideas are not illegal and that the government cannot criminalize dissent. A separate ruling by Judge William Young found the Trump administration’s crackdown on activists unlawful, as it aimed to silence criticism of Israel. Khalil remains free, but the legal saga underscores a broader conflict between immigration enforcement and free expression in the U.S.
title: Lawyers urge US appeals court to uphold Mahmoud Khalil’s release order
